A highly representative chlorinated volatile organic compound (Cl-VOCs), including 1,2-dichloroethane (1,2-DCE), which is extremely hazardous to human health and the environment. Improving the catalytic activity is very important for catalytic degradation of 1,2-DCE. In the work, CeO2@TiO2 catalyst which has a core-shell structure were made by a simple two-step hydrothermal synthesis method for 1,2-DCE oxidation. CeO2@TiO2 catalysts show higher activity (T90=275 °C), better carbon dioxide yield (YCO2=89.54 %) and lower by-products production than primitive CeO2 and TiO2. Due to its core-shell structure, CeO2@TiO2 shows the appropriate oxidation and reduction ability and appropriate acidity distribution, the powerful relationship between Ce and Ti elements in CeO2@TiO2 leads to effectively generate activity Ce3+and oxygen, which is greatly great enhance the activity of CeO2@TiO2 in 1,2-DCE catalytic oxidation. Based on the analysis of 1,2-DCE degradation performance and physical and chemical attributes, it proposes a way to catalyze 1,2-DCE catalytic oxidation over CeO2@TiO2. In addition, CeO2@TiO2 has good stability, and adding water vapor over the CeO2@TiO2 during 1,2-DCE degradation to promote 1,2-DCE conversion. The findings of this study might offer some new suggestions for creating catalysts that will destroy Cl-VOCs in their preparation and design. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 1,2-dichloroethane Catalytic destruction Core-shell structured CeO2@TiO2 Reaction mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Past few years, owing to the vigorous development of industrialization, the emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in industrial waste gas have increased. VOCs are an important factor leading to the development of secondary contaminants and photochemical haze [1]. Among them, Cl-VOCs have the characteristics of high toxicity, high environmental stability, low biodegradability and durability, which cause significant harm to human health and the environment [2]. How to eliminate Cl-VOCs economically and effectively has aroused widespread concern among researchers. Due to its low energy consumption, great stability, high selectivity and activity, catalytic degradation is considered one of the most effective technologies for decomposing low concentration Cl-VOCs [3–5]. As is well known, the catalytic oxidation degradation of Cl-VOCs typically involves the cleavage of CCl bond at acid sites i.e. the dissociation of Cl, followed by deep oxidation with intermediate CC bond cleavage, eventually producing CO2 and H2O and inorganic chlorine species(HCl and Cl2) [6]. Among them, the CCl bond is broken to form a chlorine species catalyst surface active species conversion is the cause of a large number of by-products caused by the loss of catalysts. As a result, the breakdown of the molecular structure of Cl-VOCs depends on the activation of the CCl link. In the catalytic oxidation destruction process, catalysts are susceptible to poisonous deactivation due to coking, carbon build-up and chlorination due to factors such as catalyst type, catalytic reaction temperature and water vapor content. Therefore, the development of catalysts with high performance can greatly improve the competitiveness of catalytic oxidation technology. The currently reported Cl-VOCs oxidation catalyst systems mainly focus on noble metal supporting materials [7–9], zeolite/modified zeolite [6,10,11] and metal oxides [12–14]. Generally, precious metal catalysts have relatively high catalytic activity, but they are easy to adsorb chlorine species and cause catalyst deactivation, and due to the high cost of precious metals, their application is limited; similarly, zeolite/modified zeolite will produce polychlorinated compound formation and coke the deposition and other issues. In contrast, transition metal oxides have many advantages, including low cost, strong resistance to Cl species poisoning, adjustable catalytic activity, and a wide-ranging range of applications [15,16]. Cai et al. found that doping Mn into the Co3O4 spinel structure can enhance the dispersibility of spinel, With a T90 of 347 °C, the catalysts with a Co/Mn ratio of 9 showed the most activity and stability of all of them, the catalysts with a Co/Mn ratio of nine exhibited the highest activity and stability, with a T90 of 347 °C. For example, Co- [3], Ce- [17–19], Mn- [20], Ti- [21–23], Sn- [24] and Cr- [25] based catalysts are caused by their excellent properties It has attracted widespread attention from researchers. Therefore, designing a catalyst system with multiple active sites is urgent. Among these, TiO2 has been widely used in various catalyst systems due to its stability, low cost, non-toxicity, excellent heat resistance, anti-corrosion performance and appropriate acidity, and has been widely used in various catalyst systems, for example, selective catalytic reduction of NOx and ammonia. Process (SCR) and total oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) [26–28]. According to reports, in the Cl-VOCs catalytic oxidation destruction, TiO2 can promote the oxidation–reduction and dispersion ability of transition metals, as well as increase the oxygen mobility based on the reversible Ti4+↔Ti3+ cycle [29,30]. In addition, Trawczyński et al. found that TiO2-SiO2 is a stable and corrosion-resistant carrier for TCE combustion catalysts, could effectively improve the chlorine resistance of metal oxides [31]. In addition to TiO2, pure CeO2 and CeO2 doped catalyst systems have received wide concern due to their excellent redox performance and high oxygen storage capacity. It facilitates the catalytic process by supplying oxygen storage capacity through the redox cycle between Ce3+ and Ce4+ [17,32-34]. Therefore, how to reasonably combine the benefits of TiO2 and CeO2 for catalytically breaking down Cl-VOCs is a feasible and novel study with significant environmental benefits. The performance of the catalyst is not only affected by the classification of catalysts, but also the structure plays a significant role. In recent years, core-shell nanostructures have been widely applied in the design of high-efficiency catalysts due to their unique advantages such as high stability and recyclability [35–37]. In this case, to prevent the migration of active sites and sintering at high temperatures, the active centers are isolated within the nanostructure, and to improve the catalytic performance by cooperative effect at material interfaces [38]. For example, Dai et al. [19] made a successful CeO2@HZSM-5 core-shell catalyst using in DCE oxidation. Since the CeO2 core has high activity for Deacon reaction, it can significantly inhibit the production of polychlorinated hydrocarbon. According to reports, the material often exhibits excellent catalytic activity, and its performance mainly depends on its structure, it has a high loading capacity and a big specific surface area as a core-shell composite material [39]. However, the research on the catalytic destruction of Cl-VOCs by core-shell materials is greatly overlooked. Based on the above discussion, the core-shell CeO2@TiO2 catalyst was made by a simple two-step hydrothermal synthesis way, and its catalytic destruction activity was verified by catalytic oxidation combustion of 1,2-dichloroethane (1,2-DCE). By studying the relationship between the physical and chemical properties including specific surface area, structure and structural properties, element distribution/state, oxygen mobility and surface acidity, at the same time, catalytic performance such as activity, selectivity and reaction stability, explore the Ce and Ti elements in CeO2@TiO2 composites the inherent synergy in the destruction of 1,2-DCE. At the same time, during the degradation process, the process of byproduct production was examined, and elucidating the possible degradation mechanism of 1,2-DCE. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The hydrothermal synthesis approach was used in two steps to produce the CeO2@TiO2 catalyst [40,41]. The corresponding CeO2-TiO2 sample was also prepared using a comparable hydrothermal method. For comparison, CeO2 and TiO2 samples were also produced using the similar hydrothermal synthesis method and experimental conditions. Text S1 in the supplementary documentation shows the specific material preparation process. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations In the supporting information, text S2 displays the representation and the specific representation technique that went into this article. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The detailed steps for testing catalytic activity are shown in text S3 in the supporting information. The conversion rate of 1,2-DCE (denoted as X1,2-DCE) and the productivity of CO, CO2 and COx, (written as Y CO, Y CO2 and Y COx respectively) were calculated by the following equations: (1) X 1 , 2 − D C E = C i n − C o u t C i n × 100 % (2) Y C O = C C O 2 C i n × X 1 , 2 − D C E × 100 % (3) Y C O 2 = C C O 2 2 C i n × X 1 , 2 − D C E × 100 % (4) S C O x = Y C O x X 1 , 2 − D C E × 100 % The concentrations of CO and CO2 at the outflow are C CO and C CO2, when the concentrations of 1,2-DCE at the intake are C in and C out, respectively. The reaction rate for 1,2-DCE catalytic oxidation at certain temperature should be calculated using Eq. (5): (5) r = k c = ( − A − E a R T ) c Where A represents the preexponential factor, Ea is the apparent activation energy (kJ mol-1), k represents the rate constant (s−1), and r is the reaction rate (mol s−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of samples 3.1.1 Structural and crystal properties In Fig. 1 (a), all catalysts show the different XRD patterns. The reflections of TiO2 and CeO2 nanoparticle catalysts show the typical diffraction patterns of cubic CeO2 phase and anatase TiO2, respectively. The pure CeO2 catalyst, revealed sharp reflections at 2θ of 28.8°, 33.4°, 47.6°, 56.6°, 69.3° and 76.7° should be assigned to cubic ceria (JCPDS-No.75-0120) [42]. The XRD pattern of anatase is often represented by TiO2, with diffraction peaks at roughly 25.3°, 37.0°, 48.1°, and 54.3° (JCPDS-No.99-0008) [33]. CeO2-TiO2 sample exhibits characteristic peaks including cubic CeO2 and anatase TiO2 phase. Interestingly, in contrast to the diffraction peaks of CeO2-TiO2, the CeO2@TiO2 diffraction peak may be directly associated with the diffraction peak of the face-centered cubic phase of the CeO2 structure, with a lattice constant of 5.522 Å [40]. Notably, over CeO2@TiO2, no TiO2 phase signal is found, indicating that TiO2 shell may be amorphous. No new additional peak are found, which is similar to the results of the previous report [43]. As shown in Figure.S1(a) and (b), CeO2 and TiO2 samples are tightly packed together in form of nanospheres and nanosheets, respectively. It is evident from Figure S1(c) that the CeO2-TiO2 material exhibits a significant gathering phenomena. CeO2@TiO2 catalyst exhibits the core-shell structure in Figure.S1(d-f). From EDS-mapping, it can be clearly observed that the Ce element is wrapped by Ti, which also demonstrate its core-shell structure. In Fig. 2 , it was shown the FE-TEM diagram of CeO2@TiO2 material. The CeO2@TiO2 core-shell catalysis is composed of CeO2-core and TiO2-shell with diameters of 260–300 nm and 6 nm, respectively (Fig. 2 (a)). It is possible to clearly see the CeO2@TiO2 lattice fringes from the HR-TEM image (Fig .2 (b)). The CeO2 (111) and (200) crystal planes were matched in spacing with the crystal planes at 0.312 and 0.276 nm, respectively. In Fig. 2 (c), Ti and Ce's element mapping is shown by the Ti is substantially entirely covered on the Ce, which indicates the presence of the core-shell structure. Table 1 and Fig. 1 (b, c) display the N2 adsorption-desorption characterization data, and a quantitative analysis is performed on the produced materials' specific surface area and pore size. The specific surface area, pore size, and pore volume of each synthesized samples are summarized in Table 1. CeO2@TiO2 has an area that is 4.6, 3.3, 1.4 times larger than TiO2, CeO2 and CeO2-TiO2, respectively. The CeO2@TiO2 sample has a large specific surface area (194.846 m2 g−1), which will make the surface dispersing of metal oxides higher., leading to its excellent catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 1 (b), mesopores cause the CeO2@TiO2 sample to display a conventional IV curve [41]. The sample pore size distribution curves are displayed in Fig. 1 (c). The claim that there is a mesoporous structure is true since, as the image illustrates, all catalysts have peaks that are centered at 3.8 nm. The core-shell structure of CeO2@TiO2 catalyst brings it a big specific surface area and a particular porous structure, which should enhance the interaction between reactants and the active sites, and favorable for the 1,2-DCE catalytic destruction. 3.1.2 Surface status The distribution of oxygen species over the material surface directly affects the performance of catalytic destruction of Cl-VOCs. As shown in Fig. 3 and Table 2 , the valence states and species of Ce, Ti and O elements on the material surface are analyzed by XPS characterization. From Fig. 3 (b), the O 1s XPS spectra of synthesized samples is divided into the lattice oxygen (Oα, peaks at around 529.6–530.1 eV), the surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ, peaks at around 531.7–532.1 eV) and surface hydrated oxygen (Oγ, peaks at around 533.1–533.5 eV) [44–46]. Studies have shown that the surface adsorption oxygen species over the catalyst surface have two functions. One purpose of oxygen species is to encourage the breakage of CCl bonds, thereby improving the catalytic activity at low temperatures [17]. Another function is that oxygen species can promote deep oxidation of surface intermediates through nucleophilic strike on the C atoms of adsorbed Cl-VOCs molecule [47], which helps to improve the deep oxidation of 1,2-DCE by catalysts [22]. In Table 2, CeO2@TiO2 has a higher Oβ/(Oα+ Oβ) ratio (0.72) than that of CeO2-TiO2 (0.66), CeO2 (0.54) and TiO2 (0.48), which suggest that the CeO2@TiO2 catalyst possesses the maximum amount of surface oxygen species, promoting the 1,2-DCE catalytic oxidation destruction. In Fig. 3 (c), all Ti species in the sample exist in the form of Ti4+. The XPS of Ti2p can be installed on two peaks. The peaks located at 464.6 and 458.9 eV can be the results of the orbitals of Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2, separately. The orbitals of Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 can produce the peaks at 458.9 and 464.6 eV, respectively. In Fig. 3 (d), the curve of the Ce 3d spectrum consists of four pairs of rotating orbital bimodal peaks, and divides into eight sub-peaks. While the two peaks denoted U' and V' belong to Ce3+ species, the peaks denoted U, U, U', U'', V, and V''' are associated to Ce4+ species [48]. In Table 2, CeO2@TiO2 has a litter higher Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratio (0.36) than CeO2-TiO2 (0.21), thus CeO2@TiO2 has more Ce3+ species. The violent interaction between CeO2 and TiO2 will encourage the generation of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and increased oxygen vacancies (Ce4+ + e −→ Ce3+ + ◊), reactive oxygen species movement can be efficiently accelerated by it, thereby improving catalytic oxidation activity. 3.1.3 Reducibility and oxygen species mobility The reduction, oxygen species motility of the materials were analyzed through H2-TPR and O2-TPD in Fig. 4 and Table 3 . For pure TiO2, lattice oxygen species and the reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+ are responsible for the peak that was detected at 620 °C [49]. The reduction peak of pure TiO2 is weak and occurs at higher temperatures, indicating that it is difficult to reduce TiO2. In regard to CeO2, there are two reduction peaks at approximately 535 °C and above 800 °C, respectively. These result from the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the surface of various-sized nanocrystals, whereas the bulk reduction peak is caused by the reduction of both surface and bulk oxygen [50,51]. The reduction peaks of CeO2@TiO2 as well as CeO2-TiO2 are analogous, and as a result of the Ce-Ti interaction over the catalyst, the reduction temperature of CeO2 is reduced to 760, 770 °C. In addition, CeO2@TiO2 catalyst is reduced at a lower temperature (494 °C) than CeO2-TiO2 (525 °C). This illustrates that the low-temperature reduction ability of CeO2@TiO2 is much better than CeO2-TiO2. As shown in Table 3, quantitative analysis can further verify the reduction properties of the catalyst. The total H2 consumption of these catalysts followed the order of CeO2@TiO2 (22.86 mmol g−1) > CeO2-TiO2 (20.53) > CeO2 (18.64) > TiO2 (2.58), indicating that CeO2@TiO2 has a high reduction performance. Fig. 4 (b) displays the samples' O2-TPD results. Generally speaking, the analytical temperature of oxygen species follows the following rules: the peak of 100–300 °C is considered to be physically or chemically adsorbed oxygen species (such as Oα: O2, O2 − and O−); the peak at temperatures between 300 and 600 °C is the adsorbed oxygen species over surface vacancies or superficial lattice oxygen (Oβ: Oads 2−); the peak above 600 °C is related to bulk lattice oxygen (Oγ: O2−) [52–54]. For the four catalysts, the peaks at 123.8, 125.2, 124.9, 152.3, 235.3 °C are related to the physically adsorbed oxygen species. There is a correlation between the chemically adsorbed oxygen species and the desorption peak in the 300–600 °C range. In addition, the desorption peaks above 600 °C may be related to weak surface lattice oxygen [55]. The CeO2 and TiO2 samples have tiny desorption peaks at 354.2, 495.3, 394.4 and 526.1 °C, separately, this explains why surface lattice oxygen species and surface physical and chemical oxygen species in CeO2 and TiO2 materials have weak mobility. At temperatures of 481.3, 535.2, and 661.2 °C, the CeO2-TiO2 sample shows three desorption peaks. Because of the presence of O2, O2 −, O− and Oads 2− species, the CeO2@TiO2 sample exhibits three desorption peaks at 387.3, 506.6, and 659.3 °C. As shown in Fig. 4 (b) and Table 3, the CeO2@TiO2 sample owns lagger relative peak area of oxygen species (52.74 %) than that of TiO2 (32.57 %), CeO2 (38.56 %) and CeO2-TiO2 (50.13 %), which is useful to accelerate 1,2-DCE catalytic oxidation. 3.1.4 Acidity The rich acidic sites over the catalyst surface are beneficial to activate and adsorb 1,2-DCE, thereby increasing the catalytic reaction rate and enhance the low-temperature catalytic activity of the samples [46]. NH3-TPD is a method commonly used to characterize the acidity of catalyst, to investigate surface acidic property of the prepared each catalysts. In Fig. 4 (c), the surface acidity properties of the synthesized materials in the range of 100–800 °C were analyzed. Typically, the NH3 desorption spectrum of the prepared catalyst showed three distinct peaks, which are low acidity (<200 °C), medium acidity (200–400 °C) and severe acidity (>400 °C) [56,57]. Compared to pure CeO2 and TiO2, composite oxides show more acidic sites, therefore, the composite oxide catalyst has better catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 4 (c), CeO2 exhibits two peaks at roughly 196 and 378 °C, which were related to the weak and moderate acid sites of CeO2 sample, respectively. TiO2 exhibits a desorption peak at 298 °C belonging to a moderately acidic site. The broad peaks over CeO2-TiO2 (375 °C) and CeO2@TiO2 (389 °C) samples are matched to the moderate acid sites. Similar broad peaks at 189 and 195 °C are seen in CeO2-TiO2 and CeO2@TiO2 materials, and these are linked to the weak acid sites. According to Table 3, the total quantity of NH3 desorption of the produced materials was as follows: CeO2@TiO2 (327) > CeO2-TiO2 (301) > TiO2 (186) > CeO2 (164). This indicates that the adsorption, activation, and deep oxidation of 1,2-DCE are better facilitated by catalyst materials with bigger acid sites. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Catalytic activity and selectivity In Fig. 5 (a), Over CeO2, TiO2, CeO2-TiO2 and CeO2@TiO2 catalysts, the 1,2-DCE conversion was employed as a function of reaction temperature to be examined. Generally, the required temperatures (T50 and T90, respectively) for the conversion of 1,2-DCE to 50 % and 90 % are used to judge the catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts. At a WHSV of 36,000 mL g−1 h−1, T90 values for all catalysts follow the sequence of CeO2@TiO2 (275 °C) < CeO2-TiO2 (305 °C) < TiO2 (335 °C) < CeO2 (376 °C). And T50 values for all catalysts follow the sequence of CeO2@TiO2 (234 °C) < CeO2-TiO2 (247 °C) < TiO2 (268 °C) < CeO2 (269 °C). The results show that the core-shell structured CeO2@TiO2 catalyst has the lowest reaction temperature due to the excellent oxygen migration efficiency and the promotion of surface acidity for catalytic activity. In this work, a CeO2@TiO2 composite oxide with a core-shell structure as a typical catalytic sample was studied the catalytic oxidation ability of 1,2-DCE. Fig. 5 (b) displays the reaction rates of 1,2-DCE degradation on the produced materials at 240 °C. The reaction rates over the materials are as follows the order: CeO2@TiO2 (2.75×10−10 mol g−1 s−1) > CeO2-TiO2 (2.13×10−10) > TiO2 (1.72×10−10) > CeO2 (1.59×10−10). This is clearly shown in Fig. 5 (b). The results show that the reaction rates over CeO2@TiO2 composite catalysts have favorable catalytic activity, which is an excellent catalyst of 1,2-DCE. During oxidation process, the productivity of CO and CO2 were further analyzed, as shown in Fig. 5 (c). The productivity of CO2 improves along with the increasing of temp, however, the yield of CO initially increases as the temperature increases, but because of the presence of active oxygen, as the temperature rises above around 300 °C, the CO is further oxidized CO2, resulting in significant decline in the yield of CO. As can be seen from Fig. 5 (c), at 390 °C, the CO2 yield follows the following sequence: CeO2@TiO2(89.54 %) > CeO2-TiO2(78.25 %) > TiO2(65.23 %) > CeO2(56.26 %), indicating that the construction of the nuclear shell structure to improve the performance of the catalysis, enhance the oxidation ability of the material to 1,2-DCE. In addition, in Fig. 5 (d), the relationship between 1,2-DCE conversion and COx yield was also analyzed. It can be shown that the COx yields of the catalysts at the equal 1,2-DCE conversion follow the sequence CeO2@TiO2 > CeO2-TiO2 > TiO2 > CeO2, which indicates that the CeO2 material generates more by-products during the 1,2-DCE destruction than that of other samples. 3.2.2 Long-term stability and water resistance One of the key indicators for evaluating the potential application of catalysts is the stability of the catalyst research, which is of great significance in industrial applications. The stability of all catalysts was evaluated at a temperature of approximately T90, as shown in Fig. 6 (a). During the long-term overall stability testing period, CeO2@TiO2 sample has the most outstanding catalytic stability, and the catalytic activity is maintained at 275 °C for substantially remain unchanged for about 24 h. Similarly, the catalytic stability of CeO2-TiO2 and TiO2 was relatively better at 305 and 335 °C, respectively. But after 24 h, the destructive activity of 1,2-DCE decreased by about 6.7 % and 5.9 %, respectively. While for the CeO2 samples, the destructive activity of 1,2-DCE decreased by about 10.9 % at 376 °C for 24 h. This indicates that the active sites over the surface of the samples are chlorinated after prolonged 1,2-DCE catalytic destruction, leading to chlorine poisoning. The above results indicate that CeO2@TiO2 catalyst with a core-shell structure has excellent resistance to chlorine toxicity, ensuring that it still maintains excellent 1,2-DCE destructive ability in long-term stability testing. As H2O is one of the products of Cl-VOCs degradation and exits present in industrial waste gases, it is important to analysis the effect of water vapor on the reactivity of the prepared materials for the degradation of Cl-VOCs. Here, a detailed study is conducted by adding varying amounts of water vapor (1–5 % vol.%) (Fig. 6 (b)). It has been reported that when H2O is added to the reaction atmosphere, the H2O molecules will compete with the 1,2-DCE for adsorption onto the catalysts, thereby reducing the 1,2-DCE conversion. It's interesting to note that if water vapor in volumes of 1, 2, or 5 was added to the atmosphere, the 1,2-DCE conversion rate of the catalyst slightly increased, from 90 % to about 93 %, 92 %, or 91 %, respectively. This could be as a result of the H2O molecules' low concentration efficiently eliminating Cl compounds from the catalytic surface [6,58]. In addition, the activity of catalyst is stable in the presence of water and can return to its initial level when water vapor is absent. 3.3 Proposed reaction mechanism 3.3.1 Byproduct distribution When Cl-VOCs are catalyzed to breakdown, it is usually inevitable that chlorinated by-products will grow up. Using online gas chromatography, the reaction products of the samples in the 1,2-DCE destruction were examined. CHCl3, CCl4, C2HCl3 and C2H3Cl3 were observed as incipient chlorination by-products collected at different reaction temperatures during the degradation of 1,2-DCE. The considerable variations in the amounts of chlorinated chlorination by-products found across all catalysts are displayed in Fig. 7 . It can be seen that the concentrations on CHCl3, CCl4, C2HCl3 and C2H3Cl3 over the CeO2@TiO2 catalyst were significantly below other samples. However, CeO2 possess the highest productivity of CHCl3, CCl4, C2HCl3 and C2H3Cl3 compared to other samples, indicating that CeO2 shows the worst reaction selectivity. The order of CeO2@TiO2 > CeO2-TiO2 > TiO2 > CeO2 is the reaction selectivity for COx of the produced material. In addition, the concentration of by-products on the prepared catalysts increased and then decreased as the reaction temperature increased (>250 °C). The findings demonstrate that the core-shell structure and synergistic impact of CeO2 and TiO2 can enhance their respective catalytic activities while preventing the development of 1,2-DCE breakdown byproducts. 3.3.2 In situ drifts analyses As shown in Fig. 8 , the chemical reaction method of 1,2-DCE over CeO2@TiO2, CeO2-TiO2, TiO2, CeO2 materials at different temperatures was analyzed by in situ DRIFTS measurements. Over all catalysts, the strong bands between 3429 and 3467cm−1, which are indicative of -OH vibration, and become less intense as temperature rises [56]. The band in the 1700–1200 cm−1 region has been reported to be related to adsorbed hydrocarbons and carbonate species, which are the major reasons for producing CO and CO2 [24]. For whole materials, the bands at 1639–1614 cm−1 should be related to CC stretching vibration [59], which is gradually decreased with the rise of temperature. The band at 1572–1568 cm−1 is related to the COO− asymmetric stretching over CeO2-TiO2 and CeO2@TiO2 catalysts, resulting in the generation of surface acetate species [3]. The -CH2- and -CH- groups are associated with the spectral bands around 1417–1296 cm−1, suggesting that 1,2-DCE is activated and adsorbed [60]. By way of addition, the bands at 1116–1114 cm−1 that represent the -CH- vibration are exclusively visible on CeO2-TiO2 and CeO2@TiO2 samples [61]. 3.3.3 Reaction mechanism It is evident from the aforementioned experimental findings that 1,2-DCE can be adsorbed over TiO2 shells and degraded over CeO2 cores, subsequently; achieving excellent selectivity for deep oxidation. Scheme 1 illustrated the procedure for the core-shell sample, and a possible mechanism of CeO2@TiO2 membrane for 1,2-DCE destruction. Combined with the outcomes of the distribution of DRIFTS and by-products ( Figs. 6 and 8 ), the damage mechanization of 1,2-DCE on the samples is made, in Scheme 2 . Typically, catalytic degradation of chlorinated alkanes (CA) is carried out on the basis of the following process: CA adsorption → Cl dissociation → CC/CCl cleavage → Cl desorption/accumulation [62] .Here, the key energy of the CCl key (328 KJ mol−1) is weaker than the adhesive energy of the CC key (332 KJ mol−1), which is more susceptible to attack during oxidation. Thus, the adsorption and separation of the Cl bond on the Lewis acid site is responsible for the initial adsorption of 1,2-DCE over the material surface [63]; the CCl (pathway 1) and CC (pathway 2) bonds in 1,2-DCE are then cleaved and activated to form intermediates like vinyl chloride, chloroethane, and chloromethane.the CCl (pathway 1) and CC (pathway 2) bonds in 1,2-DCE are activated and cleaved to form intermediates such as chloroethane, vinyl chloride and chloromethane. This is followed by dehydrochlorination and chlorination to produce polychlorinated by-products (CHCl3, CCl4, C2HCl3 and C2H3Cl3). HCl can be produced by the interaction of dissociative Cl with surface hydroxyl groups from polychlorinated wastes, which will be partially oxidized to form Cl2 (Dicken reaction) [63]. Further oxidize the aforementioned oxygen-containing substances to form the final products (CO, CO2, Cl2, and HCl). 4 Conclusions In the present work, CeO2@TiO2 catalyst materials with core-shell nanostructures were synthesized using a brief two-step hydrothermal method for oxidation combustion of 1,2-DCE. Compared with the original CeO2 and TiO2, CeO2@TiO2 catalyst shows excellent catalytic activity at 275 °C, higher carbon dioxide yield with 89.54 %, and the lower by-product yield. The CeO2@TiO2 of the core-shell structure has excellent molecular enrichment capabilities and a large number of Ce3+ species to show excellent reduction and active oxygen migration rate, which significantly improves activity of catalysts. Owing to a large amount of acid points on the surface of the catalyst sample and the synergy interaction between CeO2 and TiO2, the synthetic catalysts have good stability due to the inhibitory of by-products caused by the CCl/CC keys. The core-shell structure makes CeO2 and TiO2 better combine. Therefore, CeO2@TiO2 has obtained appropriate oxidation and reduction capabilities, and the appropriate acid site distribution may in turn explain its low by-product yield and 1,2-DCE oxidation ability. Therefore, this work can provide some ideas and insights for Cl-VOCs catalytic oxidation. coredata.dc:description: A highly representative chlorinated volatile organic compound (Cl-VOCs), including 1,2-dichloroethane (1,2-DCE), which is extremely hazardous to human health and the environment. Improving the catalytic activity is very important for catalytic degradation of 1,2-DCE. In the work, CeO2@TiO2 catalyst which has a core-shell structure were made by a simple two-step hydrothermal synthesis method for 1,2-DCE oxidation. CeO2@TiO2 catalysts show higher activity (T90=275 °C), better carbon dioxide yield (YCO2=89.54 %) and lower by-products production than primitive CeO2 and TiO2. Due to its core-shell structure, CeO2@TiO2 shows the appropriate oxidation and reduction ability and appropriate acidity distribution, the powerful relationship between Ce and Ti elements in CeO2@TiO2 leads to effectively generate activity Ce3+and oxygen, which is greatly great enhance the activity of CeO2@TiO2 in 1,2-DCE catalytic oxidation. Based on the analysis of 1,2-DCE degradation performance and physical and chemical attributes, it proposes a way to catalyze 1,2-DCE catalytic oxidation over CeO2@TiO2. In addition, CeO2@TiO2 has good stability, and adding water vapor over the CeO2@TiO2 during 1,2-DCE degradation to promote 1,2-DCE conversion. The findings of this study might offer some new suggestions for creating catalysts that will destroy Cl-VOCs in their preparation and design.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic combustion of 1,2-dichloroethane via CC/CCl bond cleavage through core-shell structured CeO2@TiO2 catalyst with excellent catalytic performances
